thread.title: Clashes at Ramjas College over cancellation of invite to Umar Khalid
thread.title_full: Clashes at Ramjas College over cancellation of invite to Umar Khalid

author: Jaideep Chandra Deo Bhanj
title: Clashes at Ramjas College over cancellation of invite to Umar Khalid
text:
February 22, 2017 14:54   16:41 IST more-in JNU student Khalid was arrested on sedition charge in 2016. 
Clashes broke out between members of the RSS-backed Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP) and the Left-affiliated All India Students’ Association (AISA) at Ramjas College here on Wednesday over the cancellation of a seminar invite to Jawaharlal Nehru University students Umar Khalid and Shehla Rashid. 
Mr. Khalid was arrested on sedition charge in 2016. 
Trouble started after a planned protest march by some students to the Maurice Nagar Police Station was disallowed. 
Police resorted to a lathi charge to bring the situation under control. 
No one has been detained so far yet in connection with the incident. 
PTI adds: 
ABVP on Tuesday locked down the college’s seminar room and pelted stones in protest against an invitation to the JNU students calling the two “anti-nationals“. 
College authorities had to withdraw the invitation to Mr. Khalid and Ms. Rashid. 
A section of teachers, students and members of AISA, who were agitated over the college’s decision to “bow down” to “threat to freedom of speech” had decided to march to Maurice Nagar police station demanding action against ABVP members for alleged vandalism. 
The ABVP members, however, did not allow the march to proceed and allegedly locked the students and teachers inside the college while AISA members tried to barge inside the premises to “rescue the captives“. 
“The students have been locked inside and those trying to come out were beaten up by ABVP goons. We tried to barge in inside the college to rescue the students but they are attacking us as well. They have come prepared with hockey sticks,” an AISA member said. 
College Principal Rajender Prasad said he is in discussion with the teachers who were organisers of the event and requested both the groups to not disrupt the peace and harmony in the college. 
Mr. Prasad on Tuesday claimed that though the college advocates freedom of speech, the decision to withdraw invites was taken keeping the situation in mind. 
The two JNU students were invited to take part in a session during a two-day seminar on “Culture of Protest” organised by Wordcraft, Ramjas College’s literary society.
